thread.title: Devolution one step closer: Newcastle and North Tyneside cabinets give North of Tyne plan go-ahead

author: Hannah Graham
title: Devolution one step closer: Newcastle and North Tyneside cabinets give North of Tyne plan go-ahead
text:
Who could be the first North East Mayor? 
The move will trigger a formal public consultation on the move, which will start this week and is set to come to an end at the start of February. 
Depending on the outcome of that consultation, as well as agreement from national Government, Newcastle’s council cabinet were told that the new Northern combined authority would be set up around summer 2018. 
As part of the devolution deal, the North of the Tyne authorities would be headed up by an elected mayor, who would also have influence on a national level in issues such as Brexit. Nick Forbes, leader of Newcastle City Council, Norma Redfearn, directly-elected Mayor of North Tyneside and Councillor Peter Alan Jackson, leader of Northumberland Council (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
On the creation of the new authority, an interim mayor would be appointed, holding some, but not all, of the powers of an elected mayor, with elections likely to be held in May 2019. 
The deal is set to give the councils direct control of money for housing, improving education, and schemes for business improvement and job creation. 
Nick Forbes, leader of Newcastle City Council , told his cabinet: “I think this is an extremely good first deal, I think it represents a very encouraging step forward for the region and I think it’s a great opportunity for us to start shaping our future.” Read More 
According to reports seen by the cabinets, the new authority would continue to “collaborate” with the smaller NECA, through a proposed joint transport committee and the North East Local Enterprise Partnership, which will be maintained. 
The report argues that the new £600m devolution deal will benefit the Southern authorities as well. 
It’s estimated that 25% of the predicted 10,000 jobs created by the agreement will be taken up by residents of the authorities outside the deal. 
At the moment, it remains unclear how the remaining members of NECA will respond to the three councils’ attempt to leave the group. Read More North of Tyne devolution: why are we not having a local referendum? 
In a joint statement, the four southern authorities responded to questions about their position on the deal by saying: “Our ambition to provide the best possible conditions to boost growth across the North East remains. 
“All local authorities across the region will continue to work together to create more jobs, investment and increase living standards, ensuring the North East is an excellent location to do business, live and prosper.” Like us on Facebook
